I believe it is an example of a "partial recursive function".
Pluck(arr) is an anonymous function. It is given an array arr of length n. It is told to pluck (choose a leaf node) from arr. For each node of arr, it checks if it is smaller than 0. If so, it plucks the node.
The function returns arr with one leaf node removed.
If there are no nodes in arr, or arr has only one node, the function returns []

This is a variation of the Sieve of Eratosthenes[1], but implemented as a space-efficient iterative solution using a Python list comprehension.
[1]

This is a more direct implementation of the sieve in Haskell. It works by splitting the array into a series of buckets:
fib n = sieve [0..n-1]

I believe the traditional Python solution is the one in the OP. I would never use the example given as it isn't intuitive, and it is not obvious that the solution is iterative.
The one in the OP is a very simple iterative solution.

Have a look at how it was done in PLY, an early SML dialect that dates back to 1985.
The sieve itself was implemented using a recursive function, but the same algorithm was also implemented using recursion over the integers. This is because many of the early SML compilers didn't have tail recursion optimization, but it's still a perfectly valid approach.

These days, it's best to use the iterative solution in Python, but I wanted to show how the sieve can be implemented using a list comprehension without breaking the back of the recursive function.

You've now got a perfect use case for an index based on the length of the array.
The only problem is you're using an index of "2" in your examples, which is not in any way helpful.
You could use "length - 1" as the index.
You could use any number greater than the length of the array.
So use "2" as the index, but use a bigger number in the "length - 1" case.

Note that you should never _actually_ use "length - 1" as an index, because that would
require an infinite loop to process the empty array case, and infinite loops are
bad.
